published_attributes.title: What is UX Writing?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
UX Writing and Copywriting

So you may be asking yourself, what exactly is the difference between these two? This question pops up quite often and may be a bit confusing at the start and the differences may not be as strict as one wants them to be. 

Some say Copywriting is the marketing's take on how to better sell the product using sexy words. The author needs to know the audience to lure them in and close the deal. On the other hand, a UX Writer is using a simplistic approach to reduce confusion and guide them to achieve their goal.

/Who's to say it's not conversion as well?

But is that really the case?

/Spoiler alert: no.

Initially, both Copywriting and UX Writing should be based on research and knowledge of how the end-users (or readers) behave, who they are, or what their pains and gains are.

However, the difference may lie in how they work and deliver. While UX Writing often refers to digital products and UX Writers tend to work hand in hand with the designers, developers, and stakeholders at every stage of its lifecycle, a Copywriter often creates for the physical world as well as can jump in to produce marketing content when the project is already reaching its finish line.

published_attributes.title: What is Microcopy?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Microcopy is a term that refers to small bits of text found in apps, websites, and UI. Its task is to guide and instruct users throughout their journey. These bits of copy can be found in:

  • Buttons
  • Error messages, Page 404
  • Labels in contact forms
  • Security notices
  • Conditions
  • Step-by-step instructions
  • Confirmations
  • Guidelines
  • Empty states
  • Loading messages
  • And many, many surprising places, like the What’s New section in App Store or Google Play

While interacting with digital products, anything can happen. Something wanted – successful publication, purchase, subscription to the newsletter or adding a new credit card. Something unwanted can happen, too – annoying system error, technical problems, lack of understanding of the process, or simple mistakes. Therefore, our potential user may experience a whole range of emotions during the journey – satisfaction, frustration, doubt, hope, amusement, uncertainty.

If we imagine a given process as a trip to the mountains, then the creator of microcopy will be like a guide of a given route. When it's hard, the UX Writers help, support, oversee the troubles, give valuable advice and anticipate doubts. When everything is okay, it is necessary to properly congratulate, boost positive feelings, and appreciate the user's efforts. 

In general, people judge an experience based on how they felt at its peak. By creating a huge positive peak, we have a better chance to make users remember the product.

published_attributes.title: Success and fail screens
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Positive reinforcement is a widely used tool in behavioural therapy and education. It includes all the elements that can increase the likelihood of a certain, desired behaviour. Using positive language and reinforcement works exactly the same as when talking to another person. A positive, supportive, attentive person is simply easier and more confident to talk to. As long as they are not overly enthusiastic or making jokes at the wrong moments. Then, of course, the effect will be the opposite of what was intended.

On the other hand, mistakes are and will be inherent in the life of digital products. All it takes is a poor internet connection when saving an activity, a user mistake or a system error. But errors are not something external, something separate from our brand and product. That's why the language used to communicate errors must be consistent with the tone and voice of the whole.

User-friendly error messages need to include the following: 1. What was the problem? 2. Why it happened. 3. How to solve it. 

Good practices:

  • Make boring activities fun again
  • There’s no standard copy in standard paths
  • Funny but „not-too-funny”, be mindful of the context
  • No to jargon, formal language, slang, controversy 🙅‍♀️
  • Consistency is key
  • No dead-ends
  • The call-to-action on buttons should be simple, short and clearly identify the next action (“publish” instead of “continue”)
  • If the next thing that happens doesn't match what the call-to-action says, users will be confused
  • Confusion = friction

published_attributes.title: Empty states
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Empty contact list. Empty shopping cart. Empty publication template. Empty transaction list. These spaces are the perfect tool to educate the user. There, the user not only learns what the place is for, what its potential is, but they can also be encouraged to take action – fill the cart, add a contact, start their first publication.

Takeaways:

  • Reassure users that they are doing the right thing 
  • Turn a moment of nothing into SOMETHING
  • Use a bit of emotion but making the users comfortable
  • Remember, empty states make the app more human
  • No dead-ends
  • Create easily-scannable copy with clear, brief instructions

published_attributes.title: The power of microcopy
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Waiting is a bit uncomfortable. Waiting means uncertainty, discomfort. We don’t know whether the action will be successfully completed or not. How to reduce dissonance and anxiety? The answer is: to anticipate negative emotions, keep reporting. The best practice is to suggest what awaits the user, how long it can take, and what to do when a given action lasts too long.

Good practices:

  • Call to action on buttons – plain, simple, short, and identifying the next action (“publish” instead of “continue”)
  • If the next thing that happens doesn't match what the call-to-action says, they'll be confused, and confusion = friction
  • No „bug fixes” anymore, no boring changelogs anymore
  • "What's New" sections show that real people are working on the app

The beauty of What's New section:

published_attributes.title: UX Writing Research
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Just like any other part of the design process, writing microcopy should be based on thorough research. In order to gather data on your target, it is good to establish who they are, what they do on a daily basis, what they expect to get from the product, and last but not least – how your competitors do the same job as you are about to.

Within the broad list of research methods/tools that could help establish the tone and voice are:

  • brand workshops – to establish the brand's character, personality, and look and feel
  • Google Analytics – to get to know the demographics
  • market research – to benchmark how competitors and their clients communicate
  • personas – to establish (for consistency) a clear image of the group with which you are communicating
  • empathy maps – to gain a deeper insight into the customers
  • jobs to be done – to establish user flows
  • card sorting – to research preferred messaging

published_attributes.title: Tone and voice
published_attributes.serialized_body:
What is Voice?

In short words, it is the brand's personality. Based on the product's field, the target users, and what they expect from it, a designer can determine whether the product should communicate in a Funny or Serious voice. Should it be more Casual or Formal? Try and imagine a hospital's brand materials marketing in a Funny and Irrelevant way – it most likely would be found disrespectful by most people. That's why finding the right Voice is so important – so the readers feel understood and taken care of according to what they expect.

Brand's voice can be decided on using the Four dimensions methodology, which helps position the brand between 4 contrasting dimensions:

Nielsen Norman Group describes them as:

  • Funny vs. serious: Is the writer trying to be humorous? Or is the subject approached in a serious way?
  • Formal vs. casual: Is the writing formal? Informal? Casual?  (Note that casual and conversational are not necessarily synonymous, but they do often appear together.)
  • Respectful vs. irreverent: Does the writer approach the subject in a respectful way? Or does she take an irreverent approach? (In practice, most irreverent tones are irreverent about the subject matter, in an effort to set the brand apart from competitors. They are not usually intentionally irreverent or offensive to the reader.)
  • Enthusiastic vs. matter-of-fact: Does the writer seem to be enthusiastic about the subject? Is the organization excited about the service or product, or the information it conveys? Or is the writing dry and matter-of-fact?

Note that a Voice doesn't have to fall exactly at the extremes – most of the time it will be somewhere in-between, closer to one or the other side.

data.altText: A graphing which reads "Four dimensions of tone of voice" and in four lines shows ranges from Funny to Serious, Casual and Formal, Irreverent and Respectful, Enthusiastic and Matter-of-fact. Between the contrasting words are "Neutral" boxes as "in-between" stages.

blocks.text: What is Voice?

In short words, it is the brand's personality. Based on the product's field, the target users, and what they expect from it, a designer can determine whether the product should communicate in a Funny or Serious voice. Should it be more Casual or Formal? Try and imagine a hospital's brand materials marketing in a Funny and Irrelevant way – it most likely would be found disrespectful by most people. That's why finding the right Voice is so important – so the readers feel understood and taken care of according to what they expect.
Brand's voice can be decided on using the Four dimensions methodology, which helps position the brand between 4 contrasting dimensions:
Nielsen Norman Group describes them as:
Funny vs. serious: Is the writer trying to be humorous? Or is the subject approached in a serious way?
Formal vs. casual: Is the writing formal? Informal? Casual?  (Note that casual and conversational are not necessarily synonymous, but they do often appear together.)

Respectful vs. irreverent: Does the writer approach the subject in a respectful way? Or does she take an irreverent approach? (In practice, most irreverent tones are irreverent about the subject matter, in an effort to set the brand apart from competitors. They are not usually intentionally irreverent or offensive to the reader.)

Enthusiastic vs. matter-of-fact: Does the writer seem to be enthusiastic about the subject? Is the organization excited about the service or product, or the information it conveys? Or is the writing dry and matter-of-fact?
Note that a Voice doesn't have to fall exactly at the extremes – most of the time it will be somewhere in-between, closer to one or the other side.

published_attributes.title: Tone and voice
published_attributes.serialized_body:
What is Tone?

Think of it as a situational style of communication. For example, a brand may be leaning towards casual and funny style making jokes here and there. However, when it comes to serious situations like a breach causing a data leak, they will step up with a more serious tone in order to state that they are taking the issue seriously.

Let's take a look at this example:

It doesn't sound right, does it? A customer who is facing a credit card issue is not going to laugh at the problem, they’ll get frustrated. In order to handle the situation with care and de-escalate the irritation, the tone and wording should be adjusted to explain the issue clearly, as a serious matter.

published_attributes.title: How to plan and start writing
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Many tools and methodologies have been created to make everyone’s job easier. When you have already done your research, know who your users are, and have an established branding identity, you can start working on your empathy maps, canvases and creating a Style Guide. Let’s just dive right into it and review some of them.

Microcopy Canvas

This tool can be used to align between various team members and to kick off a conversation on how you are going to build the writing style, the process of writing itself, and how to measure success. It can become a part of the Style Guide documentation later on.

Styleguide

A UX Writing Style Guide should provide all team members involved with set rules to be applied all around the product in order to maintain consistency within it. What should you include? Some of the examples can be found below:

Tone and voice

Based on your research and branding identity the tone and voice should be described in details such as:

  • Who is the audience? Are they experts in that topic or should you be more informative and assume they need more thorough explanations?
  • Formal or informal, serious, analytical or funny, joyful and enthusiastic? It can mix!
  • Are all channels of communication such as websites, apps, emails, and social media to be covered the same exact way?
  • Give some examples of how the tone should change depending on the situation. For example, should it happen that the user is in distress, the funny tone may no longer be the right option. In that case, you may advise to opt-out and stick to a more helpful tone. 

Language and grammar

  • Contractions – don’t or maybe go with more formal do not?
  • Passive or active voice 
  • Capitalization like in a sentence or rather Every Word To Be Capitalized? Maybe even FULL CAPITALS or no capitalization at all? All of them will give off a completely different vibe!
  • Should you use colons after every bullet?
  • Should you use “quotation marks” or go with indirect italics?
  • Any exclamation marks?!
  • It’s important to know how you speak to your audience – would that be a direct conversation? What pronouns will you be using?
  • US or British English?
  • The difference between “-” and “–”
  • Misusing “who”, “whom”, and “that”
  • Oxford comma or serial comma – the final comma in the list of things (at least three)
  • Going overboard with em dashes

Word bank

  • What words will you be using when referring to yourself? Is that going to be Us, Team, Product, Company, Firm or maybe something completely different? 
  • Set some rules on which words are a no-go – that could be e.g. because they seem too negative or too formal.

Inclusive language

Not everyone in your team may have the same optic and knowledge as you do on every matter. It is a good practice to include examples of how to write inclusively. That may come in handy both internally and externally! What should you watch out for?

  • Sexual orientation and gender identity
  • Ableism
  • Race and ethnicity
  • Culture and/or religion
  • Ageism

Other guidelines

  • Date and time format
  • Empty states – positive or negative?
  • CTA rules – for example, try using imperative verbs instead of plain “OK” and “Cancel” which may cause confusion

Checklists

You may want to make use of available checklists which will guide you through the process of content creation. They may also help you learn about simple language and consistency, so you never forget to check on your writing.

You will find some helpful tools in "Resources" at the end of this course.

Good practices

Tip 1: Remember to never use dummy text and Lorem ipsum while you design – you should strive to incorporate real micro/copy from the start. That way you can bring to light any issues at an early stage.

Tip 2: Always show copy in a context – users will very likely never see without it, outside of the product.

published_attributes.title: Testing
published_attributes.serialized_body:
So, when you've done your fair share of research, looked through nooks and crannies to get to know the users, market, established the brand's tone and voice, and finally got some writing done it's time to TEST!

One may again ask themselves, but how do you test... text? It's just letters, right? Well, the same as any other form of design – show it to the users and see how they react. 🤷🏻

The testing frameworks worth mentioning are:

  • 5-second test
  • Usability testing
  • Comprehension surveys
  • Tree testing
  • A/B Testing
  • Cloze testing
  • Highlighter testing
  • ...and more!

Let's have a closer look at some of them, which you may not be familiar with yet.

Cloze testing

The result of cloze test is a number of a formal education grade level needed to understand the text. For example, the readability of this article is Grade 7 which corresponds to a roughly 11 years old person.

How to run a cloze test

  1. Choose a piece of text and replace every Nth word with blanks. Usually, texts have N=6, but you can make it even easier by increasing the N number! However, working with microscopy may require a lower N, since the snippets are very short.
  2. Ask your participant to read the text you have prepared and fill the gaps with words they find the most fitting.
  3. As the last step, calculate how many out of all the missing words the recipient has guessed correctly. In this case, the higher, the better. A result of 60% or more would mean the text has an average readability level.

You could also run your text through readability formulas.

Highlighter testing

With this tool, you will be able to measure if the written text gives out the right feeling, emotion, and information you wanted to pass.

How to run highlighter testing

  1. Same as before, first choose a piece of text (around 125-250 words) and decide what you want to test against. Make a list of factors and each code with a corresponding highlighter color.
  2. The next step would be giving your respondents printouts of the text and asking them to mark all the words and phrases which correspond to the categories you are testing for.
  3. When they are finished, you can ask your users why they have marked certain parts to gain deeper knowledge on how they perceive them.
  4. Sum up the highlights and analyze them to check what may need rewriting.

Comprehension surveys

You may be familiar with this method as it is based on quizzing the respondent about the content of the text they had just read. This is to check if it is easy to understand. Ring a bell? Yep, school reading comprehension tests!

How to run a comprehension survey

  1. Choose the text you would like to test.
  2. Create a list of questions corresponding to the text. As it is a quantitative method, an online survey platform will do the best job).
  3. Set up a timer (20 min should be enough, don't go overboard) and provide the respondents with the copy and questionnaire.
  4. Now you can calculate their scores and see what seems to be most problematic and to what degree. If you've used an online platform like SurveyMonkey it may do the counting for you.

Have you ever tested your copy? How did you do it and what have you learned? Don't hesitate to share below!

blocks.text: So, when you've done your fair share of research, looked through nooks and crannies to get to know the users, market, established the brand's tone and voice, and finally got some writing done it's time to TEST!
One may again ask themselves, but how do you test... text? It's just letters, right? Well, the same as any other form of design – show it to the users and see how they react. 🤷🏻
The testing frameworks worth mentioning are:
5-second test
Usability testing
Comprehension surveys
Tree testing
A/B Testing
Cloze testing
Highlighter testing
...and more!
Let's have a closer look at some of them, which you may not be familiar with yet.
Cloze testing

The result of cloze test is a number of a formal education grade level needed to understand the text. For example, the readability of this article is Grade 7 which corresponds to a roughly 11 years old person.
How to run a cloze test

Choose a piece of text and replace every Nth word with blanks. Usually, texts have N=6, but you can make it even easier by increasing the N number! However, working with microscopy may require a lower N, since the snippets are very short.
Ask your participant to read the text you have prepared and fill the gaps with words they find the most fitting.

As the last step, calculate how many out of all the missing words the recipient has guessed correctly. In this case, the higher, the better. A result of 60% or more would mean the text has an average readability level.
You could also run your text through readability formulas.
Highlighter testing
With this tool, you will be able to measure if the written text gives out the right feeling, emotion, and information you wanted to pass.
How to run highlighter testing
Same as before, first choose a piece of text (around 125-250 words) and decide what you want to test against. Make a list of factors and each code with a corresponding highlighter color.
The next step would be giving your respondents printouts of the text and asking them to mark all the words and phrases which correspond to the categories you are testing for.
When they are finished, you can ask your users why they have marked certain parts to gain deeper knowledge on how they perceive them.
Sum up the highlights and analyze them to check what may need rewriting.
Comprehension surveys

You may be familiar with this method as it is based on quizzing the respondent about the content of the text they had just read. This is to check if it is easy to understand. Ring a bell? Yep, school reading comprehension tests!
How to run a comprehension survey
Choose the text you would like to test.
Create a list of questions corresponding to the text. As it is a quantitative method, an online survey platform will do the best job).
Set up a timer (20 min should be enough, don't go overboard) and provide the respondents with the copy and questionnaire.
Now you can calculate their scores and see what seems to be most problematic and to what degree. If you've used an online platform like SurveyMonkey it may do the counting for you.
Have you ever tested your copy? How did you do it and what have you learned? Don't hesitate to share below!

published_attributes.title: Tips and Tricks
published_attributes.serialized_body:
UX Writing Top 10

🖤 Simple is the new black. Writing is simple. All you have to do is cross out the wrong words. Mark Twain

🏄 Working with the flow. A big no-no to: Just add a copy to that single screen.

🔎 Predict the predictable. Stay ahead of the questions.

🧁 Humour is just the icing on a cake. Injecting a bit of the casual and friendly tone of verbal conversation into your writing is a good thing.

✍️ Write naturally, the way you talk. Simplifying the vocabulary – when done deliberately and thoughtfully – can make your writing more engaging and easier to read. Shorter sentences sound way more natural.

⚖️ No shaming. Protect the general well-being of your audience. Forget about messages like Our marketing manager will be fired because you’re cancelling our subscription.

🏋️ Creativity takes courage. Read a lot, write a bit every day, analyze effects  – eventually, it will become more natural to you, and you will start having fun with the experiments. 

🌎 Use down-to-earth language. The use of professional jargon arises negative reactions. There is always a simple, down-to-earth word that says the same thing.

✂️ Short paragraphs, short sentences, short words. Make your first paragraph short and crisp to get the reader's attention. Prefer short words to long ones that mean the same thing.

​​🔄 Iterations, iterations. Once we are done writing, we should go back and polish our work. Accept that first drafts are almost always crap.
